item.title: Embedding machine code in Zig instead of using inline assembly
item.description: Linux and macOS Rosetta notes Assembling Calling from Zig A larger example with fast memcpy and syscalls Zig supports inline assembly, which is useful when: Writing an operating system, which requires direct access to special CPU registers and controllers Implementing syscalls in a standard library Accessing microcontroller features on an embedded system Handwriting a performance-critical hot-path function where the optimizer isn’t up to the task This post explores an alternative: write the assembly in separate files, run your favorite assembler, and then embed the resulting machine code using @embedFile.
